qas.question: Many of the big players in the post-punk scene began leaning away from what as time progressed?
What did the magazines catering to post-punk interest do to alienate their readers?
Which magazine tied to the post-punk movement lost half of its circulation?
What did the club-oriented scene emphasize instead of the experimental seriousness of earlier post-punk groups?
What did authors and artists begin advocating for instead of the underground scene?
What began to alienate the readers from publications such as NME?
Who did Paul Morley collaborate with on the Art of Noise?

answers.text: engineer Gary Langan and programmer J. J. Jeczalik

qas.question: What did the Art of Noise hope to accomplish?

answers.text: attempt to bring sampled and electronic sounds to the pop mainstream

qas.question: Which new cultural movement began to emphasize glam, escapism and fashion?

plausible_answers.text: engineer Gary Langan and programmer J. J. Jeczalik

qas.question: Who did Morley not want to collaborate with?

plausible_answers.text: ABC, the Associates, Adam and the Ants and Bow Wow Wow

qas.question: What scene did not emphasize fashion or glamour?
What music genre never had writing publications?

context: However, during this period, major figures and artists in the scene began leaning away from <a0_0>underground aesthetics<a0_0/>. In the music press, the <a1_0><a6_0>increasingly esoteric writing<a6_0/><a1_0/> of <b14_0>post-punk<b14_0/> publications soon began to alienate their readerships; it is estimated that within several years, <a2_0>NME<a2_0/> suffered the loss of half its circulation. Writers like <a3_0>Paul Morley<a3_0/> began advocating "<a5_0>overground brightness<a5_0/>" instead of the experimental sensibilities promoted in early years. Morley's own musical collaboration with <a7_0><b10_0>engineer Gary Langan and programmer J. J. Jeczalik<b10_0/><a7_0/>, the Art of Noise, would <a8_0>attempt to bring sampled and electronic sounds to the pop mainstream<a8_0/>. A variety of more pop-oriented groups, including <b11_0>ABC, the Associates, Adam and the Ants and Bow Wow Wow<b11_0/> (the latter two managed by former Sex Pistols manager Malcolm McLaren) emerged in tandem with the development of the <a9_0><b12_0><b13_0>New Romantic<b13_0/><b12_0/><a9_0/> subcultural scene. Emphasizing <a4_0>glamour, fashion, and escapism<a4_0/> in distinction to the experimental seriousness of earlier post-punk groups, the club-oriented scene drew some suspicion from denizens of the movement.
